body:
Excellent, polytheist, now go to verse 9:

"Love must be sincere. Hate what is evil; cling to what is good"

And the letter is adressing the community in Rome. The early "Christian" communities didn't intermingle with the general population, nor did they practise Roman patriotism (quite the opposite). 

Paul also said that the citizenship of the elect (not Christians) was not in the world, but in heaven. And Jesus himself said his followers (not Christians) were not of the world, and 1 John 5 says the world is in the hand of the evil one.

So much for your devout faith, huh? 

And btw, what was the name of the hospital and surgeon where you saw a magical tumour (that didn't at all behave like any tumour) miracoulusly removed?

body:
They worship a human being as God and beside God, and a satanic, man-made triad-idol, when they've been explicitly commanded to acknowledge and worship the one God alone. They try to circumvent and nullify God's clear-cut commandments with semantic gymnastics. They are are doctrinally required to lie. They twist and pervert scripture as they see fit. They claim to be indwelled and guided by God's spirit, and to personally know Jesus of Nazareth when they are willful idolaters. They just can't stop lying and contradicting themselves. 

The poster I replied to also -- when on the subject of miracles -- claimed to have experienced (in reality it's probably a second, third or fourth hand account) someone that has an inoperable tumour with "tentacles" all over the brain, but when doctors operated it wrapped itself up to a neat ball to be removed. Yet he won't give the surgeon's name, the name of the hospital, the name of any nurse or doctor, or explain why they operated an inoperable tumour, or why it hasn't been documented in any single medical journal. He's just a typical liar. 

He also claims to be a devout Christian, but worships a wordly empire above the tenets of his own faith, as is typical of politico-religious American Evangelicalism.

It's pretty hard to deny. Did you know that "God" is plural? The word used is ê§Äê§ãê§Ñê§âê§å. As you can see it ends in ê§âê§å, which denotes a *plural noun*. It is the third word of genesis and is used quite frequently in the old testament. When speaking, He sometimes refers to himself as "us" or "we".

And references are repeatedly made to "the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit", all of which are worshipped.

> (not Christians!)

That doesn't make any sense, can you elaborate on this?

May I ask what your beliefs are?
